review_title: Not explaining the pay before purchasing a vehicle
pros: Absolutely nothing about working for Lift
cons: They are no way to make nothing on Lift ....even if you do 120 rides or more cause everything you make goes directly to Lift because everything you make goes to the whole rental payment for the week...first...then when they get the whole $345 you made doing Lift..your back to $0 and anything you make after that isn't yours until you make your rental payment again....so make nothing and you pay out of your pocket for gas 3 or 4 times to fill your tank and they don't reimburse you for gas you put everyday you have to put in the Lift rental vehicle..so I would never recommend no one to work for Lift..waist of time&money

pros: They are family! They understand and get you along.

pros: I can deposit my earnings the same day.
cons: The way they assign the trips.

pros:
The primary reason I joined LIFT was for its commitment to anti-racism. It's front and center in everything we do and the organization and its leaders really put the walk behind the talk which I so much appreciate.

LIFT's mission to break the cycle of poverty and how we go about it, by partnering our members with coaching on life skills and helping our members make a plan to reach their goals is truly inspiring. I love hearing about our members' success stories and enjoy seeing the passion our staff has for helping to improve the quality of their lives using hope, money, and love.

I connect with our values: Equity, Diversity, Excellence, Relationships, and Hope. And I like seeing them throughout what we do especially with our annual values awards (LIFTies) where we chose an employee per value that has demonstrated that value for the past year.

We're a hard working team that emphasizes balancing off time as well. I appreciate the focus on taking time for ourselves, prioritizing time off and mental health breaks.
cons: I don't have any cons. It really feels like my dream organization - an amazing mission with people passionate about it, a focus on anti-racism and being part of a growing non-profit.

pros: Leadership, work-life-balance, helpful teammates, great culture
cons: Compensation, can have really busy sprints, role clarity

review_title: Its a great Organization with an awesome work/life balance
pros: Great team members and growing company
cons: Not any I can think of

review_title: Meaningful work but workflow challenges, & high turnover
pros: Helping low-income families. Alleviating poverty. Community involvement.
cons: High turnover rate in key positions and leadership. Accountability and ability to adapt to changing environments/conditions can be slow. Training isn't robust as it could be. Strategies tend to be reactive then data-driven. Small teams which requires equity in workload to succeed isn't always present. Must be able to operate in their framework, which can limit outside approaches/perspectives to problems.

pros: great team and work life
cons: stressful and self management needed

review_title: Strong culture, dedicated team members and impactful mission.

job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Learning organization - works to improve internal systems collectively. Agile in examining model and improving. Centers voices of communities we serve.
cons: Need more opportunities for growth.

pros: Amazing atmosphere, great people, great mission, positive.
cons: Opportunities can be shy, pay should be better

pros: Great culture, inspiring leadership, strong collaboration
cons: Nothing but good things to say

pros: LIFT has been moving forward in a number of ways, they have totally revamped and replaced most of their development and finance staff and that has greatly improved their ability to operate Nationally. Their program has been innovative, but also effective in where it is being implemented. The staff is wonderful and dedicated. The President and CEO are so hard working it blows me away that they are still able to do so much and just be two people. The Americorps members are very dedicated too and always such a great presence to work with.
cons: They need to hone their focus even more. This has been tough with LIFT in the past, but they are getting very close and I have faith once they do make this strategic push that they will really be making ground.

pros: LIFT does really important work and is, truly, a mission-driven organization. The members that regional staff get to work with are amazing and so important to the daily work. The staff care about work/life balance and encourage taking time off to disconnect. The benefits are wonderful and are hard to match at other non-profits.
cons: LIFT tries to operate like a large organization with a small staff team. This leads to burnout, miscommunication, frustration and exhaustion. There are always massive new projects with new expectations and short deadlines. Unfortunately, they rarely get communicated to "junior" staff with satisfactory time to deliver. It's exhausting to work at LIFT and, on top of that, there's always "no room in the budget" for raises and no room to grow in the organization's structure.

review_title: Smart, mission driven and high impact team
pros:
My colleagues are some of the highest quality people I've met. Team is laser focused on delivering impact for the communities we serve and the approach mixes passion/heart with a smart, data driven approach. 

The culture embraces diversity and champions equity. It's also fast-paced, innovative and flexible - we adapt to our communities and hire colleagues who can learn, build and change with us. 

Leadership has a big vision for changing the narrative around families who are low income and is willing to take a stand on issues that matter. They've also invested in creating a diverse team, all the way up to the top.
cons: No major cons to working at LIFT.

review_title: Great mission and good people but some mismanagement
pros: Super smart and passionate people who are dedicated to the mission and are really caring and supportive of their colleagues. People are innovative and thoughtful and always trying to improve the program and drive impact. Also, good work/life balance and very supportive of working parents.
cons: At times, there has been issues of transparency between senior leadership and staff. As the organization has grown, it has been harder to maintain that sense of community and collaboration that once made LIFT great. There were too many layers of bureaucracy.

review_title: In a time of change and experimentation
pros: Passionate, well-intentioned, and mission-driven people. Organization is willing to ask hard questions of itself and its work. Appetite for learning and following current trends in antipoverty space; not stuck in status of quo of services or programs. Generous employee benefits, culture promoting work-life balance, and flexibility.
cons: Follow-through does not always live up to intentions. Trust in leadership and management is problematic. With desire to maintain relevance and increase impact as a leader in fighting poverty, comes risk of moving too quickly without expertise or experience in new programmatic directions. Marketing and communications can outpace program.

review_title: Great Mission not so great staff
pros: Mission driven, Flexible hours, good location, purposeful
cons: Diversity, Employee Appreciation, Honesty, Culture, Capable employees, No Innovation

pros: Amazing work is constantly being done! While it is a referral agency, it definitely feels more like direct services as we typically do as much as we can in the time allocated. I highly recommend this experience as it helps one get connected to many of Los Angeles's support networks.
cons: Sometimes the work can feel very stressful because you are working with very urgent and dire cases on the regular, but as long as you maintain a good work-life balance, you should leave LIFT a stronger person for it.

pros: Volunteering here is phenomenal - you get an incredible experience and learn a LOT.
cons: Being a FT employee was slightly different as far as transparency from the National Office went - I would have loved more of that. Program-wise, voices from the ground-level employees was solicited, but never seemed to change anything logically. The standardization that continued to occur within the last year and a half at LIFT severely limited our impact with our clients and was tough to explain to volunteers.

review_title: Wonderful culture, talented people, important work
pros: LIFT has been a wonderful place to work. They have a welcoming culture with managers who truly care for their employees. I had a great work-life balance while also having plenty of opportunity to contribute to the larger mission through my work. Other pros include: Amazing benefits for the industry. Some of the smartest, hardest working colleagues I've ever had. Powerful impact on the families we worked with. Focus on DE&I internally.
cons: The only downside I experienced was lack of high-quality technology for lower-level employees, which is something they are working to address and has been slowly improving over the last few months.

pros: Great people.  Great mission.  Great experience.  I learned a lot and loved what I did.  I would recommend it to anyone wishing to have a direct impact on a community.
cons: The pay made it somewhat difficult to enjoy a life in Chicago, but it was definitely worth it for a couple of years.  The fact that the company is so young means that it can tend to go through a lot of drastic changes and growing pains, but again, still worth it for a great mission.

review_title: In a time of change, LIFT's National Office did little
pros: My former co workers were some of the kindest, most empathetic people I have ever had the pleasure of meeting.
cons: I worked at LIFT for less than a year and throughout that time I was informed of many organizational changes that made it difficult to fulfill my work obligations. I was informed the regional office I worked at would be closing two and a half months after I started. As an AmeriCorps volunteer, I felt unappreciated (but mostly ignored) by our National Office and over worked. My immediate supervisors were also over worked, which prevented them from providing me with the support I needed to do my job.

pros: LIFT works hard to ensure that all staff are heard, respected, and appreciated. They are an innovator in their field and work hard to make the work data-driven and constituent led. It's been around for 20 years and it's unofficial motto is Hope. Money. Love. They really try to bring the love to the work and to lead with compassion and empathy.
cons: As with many other nonprofits and small organizations, money is spent frugally. Staff often feel overworked, but there is also ample Paid Time Off and flexibility if needed.

pros:
- Incredibly smart, dedicated, and inspiring colleagues
- Focused on delivering high-impact programs that put community members first; value-driven organization that is constantly reassessing what it can do better
- Fun and supportive culture that values employees as human beings
- Very competitive benefits package for social sector (26 paid vacation days + all federal holidays, fully paid health insurance, etc.)
cons: Like most nonprofits, resources are tight -- which can lead to long hours if you're not careful about proactively managing your workflow

job_title: Work Study Student in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
-The clients are incredible.  They come from  all over the world (Trinidad, Sierra Leone, Dominica, Mauritania, Ethiopia) and I have learned something from each and every person who walked through LIFT's doors.  Everyone had a story, and I feel truly privileged that the clients were gracious enough to share with us their successes and struggles. LIFT is a great opportunity for students like myself to gain experience with a wide variety of populations: the recently incarcerated, individuals with mental illness, people with disabilities, single parents, and the homeless, among others.  The clients had a variety of life goals which kept my days very interesting: you had people who wanted to pursue nursing, entrepreneurship, culinary school, and criminal justice.  I admire the strength of LIFT's clients and their dedication to both their families and their community. 

-Exposure to a wide variety of public and private agencies: clients encountered a variety of obstacles in their life ranging from foreclosure to domestic violence to unemployment and everything in between.  I learned a tremendous amount about federal and state benefits, as well as specialized services in my city such as health clinics, shelters, parenting classes, college readiness programs, immigrant welcome centers, free legal advocates....anything you could imagine.  This knowledge is invaluable for any student who wants to prepare for government employment, non-profit jobs, or work in human services.  I am a more discerning reader of social policy research and a stronger activist thanks to my experience at LIFT.
cons:
-Shortsighted strategic growth plan: I had been thinking about writing a Glassdoor review of LIFT for several months now, but I'm glad I waited.  If you had asked me to rate LIFT earlier in 2015, I would have given the organization 2 or 3 stars.   In wake of LIFT's recent decision to close three of its offices, a 2-star review would be providing this nonprofit with far too much credit.  How could LIFT in good conscience shutter its doors in three of America's largest cities, depriving thousands of existing clients from accessing vital services?  The organization has a growing base of donors, so this decision was not for lack of funding.  I am truly disgusted by LIFT's blatant disregard for its own core values: "Collaboration," "Service," "Relationships," and "Human Potential."  LIFT was a lifeline for many community members when other organizations turned their back.  No other organization in my city had such a strong commitment to eliminating red tape and to serving ALL residents, no referral or documentation needed. 

 In the words of one client, "without LIFT a lot of people would have no hope."  I fear for the wellbeing of LIFT clients.  The truth is that many organizations are simply at a point of saturation and have no room to provide new clients with assistance.  LIFT's management claims the decision was made to focus services on children and family, but do they realize the harm they have caused to families in Boston, Chicago, and Philadelphia affected by the closure?  LIFT could have invested in better resources for children/families by providing employees in these offices with additional training and piloting new programs, but instead they thought it would be more effective to simply shut down half of their offices nationwide.  This is irresponsible on so many levels: not only for the clients and employees, but for the donors who provided grants to these specific branches.  In the case of Philadelphia, a construction company generously remodeled the office six months prior to the closure (which by the way, was only announced one month in advance).  Had they known about the closure earlier, they most likely would have invested in a different organization more committed to longevity. 

-Disorganized supervisors:  administration at local LIFT offices is a revolving door. These positions are primarily staffed by Americorps members, most of whom are fresh out of college and know scarcely more what they are doing than student workers (in many cases, less).   My supervisors would depict themselves as a "resource," but they answered our questions by telling us to simply use Google.  Some of my supervisors were new to the city and had very limited knowledge about local organizations.   Most frustrating was the lack of communication between the supervisors.  The Americorps management team at the Philly office was outrageously bloated (six supervisors), and they were not on the same page with each other.  Many of us student workers got formally disciplined for following the advice of a supervisor, because another supervisor would tell us it was inaccurate.  Contradicting instructions were rampant, and we never knew which supervisor was giving us correct information. We were constantly breaking policies that we didn't know existed, and almost every day I would leave the office feeling demoralized.  


-Wasted opportunities:  I often thought that LIFT could be doing so much more to help clients.   For months on end, I'd feel like we were just spinning wheels: shooting out online job applications for every hotel in Philadelphia and then starting all over again.  Many administrators and board members are well-connected: why couldn't they have brought recruiters into the office?  hosted a job fair? collaborated with other organizations to develop on-site training programs? We were constantly shuttling off clients to other places to get CPR certified, enroll in GED coursework, take Home Health Aide exams, complete coding classes, etc. Some of these weren't viable options for clients due to transportation or financial barriers (or programs that simply reached  full capacity). Providing more on-site services would have been immensely beneficial for clients, but workers who suggested this got shot down. 

 On a similar note: why not collect nonperishable foods to give to clients? My heart broke every time I had to tell a client that we couldn't provide them with food. For many clients, food pantry hours were not compatible with their schedules or they couldn't afford the bus token to make it to a pantry.  I raised this issue with several supervisors and they simply told me that LIFT is about "teaching people to fish."  The clients were trying their darndest to "fish," but an elderly lady with a walker simply cannot walk half a mile to pick up canned goods in the blazing heat.  

LIFT's unresponsiveness to a clients' needs for bus/subway tokens cost many clients valuable opportunities.A client of mine was thrilled to land an interview at a convenience store, but the only location that was hiring was in the other side of the city. He had to decline the interview because he had exhausted all his savings and could not afford a single subway token.   If LIFT can afford new office furniture, a Keurig machine, pizza for the staff, a big screen TV for the reception area, etc., then they could afford to provide clients with an occasional token for emergency situations.

pros: LIFT has an extremely positive culture that welcomes all perspectives in finding creative solutions to eliminating systemic poverty.  It has been successful in implementing a unified program model in locations across the country while also maintaining a close-knit feel in throughout the organization.
cons: As with most nonprofits LIFT is trying to tackle very large issues in society with limited resources.

pros: It is a great environment. The staff is amazing and the customers bright up my day
cons: Sometimes people come in with problems that we cannot solve, and there are very little resources for them.

review_title: Great professional opportunity, some growing pains
pros: supportive environment, valued self-care and professional development. Great opportunity to build skills in my career. Mission-driven, passionate colleagues.
cons: LIFT is bold and innovative and growing quickly. This resulted in some growing pains during my year with LIFT. I believe they have the leadership to grow and succeed.

pros: It was a god job good experience
cons: A lot of young people work there that’s a AmeriCorps. It’s no real connection to the agency a lot of free labor

pros: Lots of independence. Will learn a lot. Challenging and rewarding. Great office atmosphere and people.

review_title: Love my time here thus far

pros: True desire to be a top tier non-profit, with quality programs and people.  Good intentions.
cons: Founder-itis. All spin, no reality. Senior exec team isolates themselves.  Extremely high turnover rate and paranoia.

pros: Good people to work with

pros: Everyone who works here is SUPER nice. The company culture is amazing.
